The morning mist clung to the rolling hills outside Kitchener like a gossamer shroud, and Andrius Kavaliauskas pulled his worn woolen coat tighter against the October chill. His breath formed small clouds in the crisp air as he counted his flock, the familiar ritual bringing him the same quiet satisfaction it had for the past seven years. Twenty-three sheep, all accounted for, their woolly forms dotting the green pasture like scattered cotton balls against an emerald canvas.

From the ridge above, he could see the city sprawling in the distance, its glass towers catching the first golden rays of sunrise. Sometimes he wondered what it would be like to live among all those people, rushing about their daily business in suits and ties, but the thought never lingered long. This was his world, simple and peaceful, where the biggest concern was whether old Bertha would wander too close to the creek again or if the weather would hold for another week of good grazing.

A whistle echoed across the valley, and Andrius felt his heart skip in that familiar way it had been doing lately. Marcus was approaching from the eastern trail, his tall frame silhouetted against the brightening sky. They had been meeting like this almost every morning for three months now, ever since Marcus had started taking his daily runs through the countryside to escape what he called "the suffocating embrace of suburban life."

Marcus Chen worked as a graphic designer downtown, something that seemed impossibly glamorous and mysterious to Andrius, though he would never admit it. While Andrius spent his days with sheep and sky and the whisper of wind through grass, Marcus created advertisements and logos and websites for companies whose names Andrius couldn't even pronounce properly. Yet somehow, despite their vastly different worlds, they had fallen into an easy friendship that felt as natural as breathing.

"Morning, shepherd boy," Marcus called out as he jogged closer, his running shoes squelching slightly in the dew-damp earth. His dark hair was tousled from the wind, and there was a flush in his cheeks that made Andrius's stomach flutter in ways he was still trying to understand.

"Morning, city boy," Andrius replied with a grin, using their usual greeting. "You're later than normal. Traffic jam on the trail?"

Marcus laughed, bending over to catch his breath. He was wearing those tight running clothes that made Andrius forget what he was saying sometimes. "Actually, I got distracted by something interesting on my way here. There's this new coffee shop that just opened on King Street, and they've got this amazing mural on the side wall. Made me think about art and permanence and all that philosophical stuff that keeps me up at night."

This was one of the things Andrius loved most about Marcus, the way his mind worked, jumping from topic to topic like a butterfly sampling flowers. Andrius's own thoughts moved more like his sheep, steady and purposeful and occasionally stubborn. Together, they seemed to balance each other out in a way that felt almost magical.

"Speaking of permanent things," Marcus continued, straightening up and walking closer, "I've been thinking about getting a tattoo. Something meaningful, you know? Not just some random design, but something that represents who I am, where I come from, what matters to me."

Andrius felt something twist in his chest, though he couldn't quite identify what it was. "What kind of tattoo?"

"I'm not sure yet. Maybe something that incorporates my heritage, or represents my work, or..." Marcus paused, looking directly at Andrius with those warm brown eyes that seemed to see straight through to his soul. "Or maybe something that represents the people who've become important to me."

The air between them seemed to shimmer with unspoken possibilities, and Andrius felt his mouth go dry. He wanted to say something meaningful, something that would let Marcus know how much their friendship meant to him, how the best part of his day was always this moment when Marcus appeared on the horizon. But the words felt too big and dangerous, so instead he just nodded and looked out over his flock.

"That sounds nice," he managed finally, his voice coming out rougher than intended.

Marcus was quiet for a moment, and when Andrius glanced back at him, there was something almost disappointed in his expression. But it passed so quickly that Andrius wondered if he had imagined it.

"Anyway," Marcus said, his tone becoming more casual, "I should probably head back soon. I've got a client meeting at nine, and I still need to shower and pretend I'm a responsible adult who doesn't spend his mornings running around talking to sheep herders."

"Shepherds," Andrius corrected automatically.

"Right, shepherds. Much more dignified." Marcus's smile was teasing, but there was genuine warmth in it that made Andrius's chest feel tight. "Same time tomorrow?"

"Same time tomorrow," Andrius agreed, watching as Marcus turned and began jogging back toward the city. He stood there until the other man disappeared over the ridge, then spent the rest of the morning trying to convince himself that the strange ache in his chest was just indigestion from the leftover pierogi he'd eaten for breakfast.That evening, Andrius sat at his small kitchen table, a cup of tea growing cold in his hands as he stared out the window toward the lights of Kitchener twinkling in the distance. The farmhouse had belonged to his grandfather, then his father, and now him, each generation adding their own touches while maintaining the essential character of the place. The wooden floors creaked with familiar sounds, and the walls held the accumulated warmth of decades of family meals and quiet conversations. It was a good life, he reminded himself, exactly the kind of life his grandparents had dreamed of when they first immigrated from Lithuania with nothing but hope and determination.

But tonight, something felt different. Marcus's words about tattoos and meaningful things kept echoing in his mind, along with that look he'd given him, as if he were waiting for Andrius to say something important. The problem was, Andrius had never been good with words, especially when his feelings were involved. Growing up in a family where emotions were expressed through actions rather than declarations had left him woefully unprepared for moments that seemed to require poetry.

His phone buzzed on the table, and he nearly knocked over his tea cup in his haste to check it. A text from Marcus: "Thanks for listening to me ramble about tattoos this morning. Sometimes I think you're the only person who actually hears what I'm trying to say." There was a pause, then another message: "Do you ever feel like you're living two different lives? Like there's the person you are in public and then there's who you really are when no one's watching?"

Andrius stared at the screen for a long time, his thumbs hovering over the keyboard. He wanted to tell Marcus that yes, he understood exactly what that felt like, that sometimes he felt like he was performing the role of the simple shepherd when inside he was someone much more complicated. He wanted to say that the only time he felt completely himself was during those morning conversations on the hill, when the rest of the world seemed to fade away and it was just the two of them and the endless sky. Instead, he typed back: "I think everyone feels that way sometimes."

It wasn't enough, he knew as soon as he hit send. It was safe and noncommittal and probably not what Marcus needed to hear. But before he could figure out how to say what he really meant, Marcus had replied: "You're probably right. I should let you get some sleep. Sweet dreams, shepherd boy."

Andrius set the phone aside and rubbed his temples, frustrated with himself and his inability to bridge the gap between what he felt and what he could express. Outside, he could hear the sheep settling in for the night, their soft bleating carrying on the autumn breeze. Tomorrow would bring another morning, another chance to get it right, but he couldn't shake the feeling that opportunities were slipping through his fingers like water.

The next morning dawned gray and overcast, with the kind of persistent drizzle that seemed designed to dampen spirits as well as clothing. Andrius pulled on his rain jacket and made his usual rounds, checking on the flock and making sure they had adequate shelter from the weather. The sheep seemed unbothered by the rain, but Andrius found himself glancing repeatedly toward the eastern trail, wondering if Marcus would still come for his run in conditions like these.

When the familiar whistle finally echoed across the valley, Andrius felt a relief so profound it surprised him. Marcus appeared through the mist wearing a bright yellow rain jacket that made him look like a beam of sunshine against the gray landscape. His hair was plastered to his head, and he was grinning with the kind of reckless joy that came from embracing rather than fighting the elements.

"Crazy weather for a run," Andrius called out as Marcus approached, having to raise his voice slightly over the sound of rain pattering against his jacket hood.

"Are you kidding? This is perfect weather for thinking," Marcus replied, shaking droplets from his hands. "There's something about rain that makes everything feel more honest, don't you think? Like it washes away all the pretense and leaves just the essential stuff behind." He paused, studying Andrius's face with that intense way he had that made Andrius feel simultaneously seen and exposed. "I've been thinking about our conversation yesterday, about tattoos and meaningful things. And I realized I wasn't being completely honest."The rain seemed to intensify around them as Marcus spoke, creating a curtain of privacy that made the moment feel suspended from the ordinary world. Andrius felt his heart begin to beat faster, though he couldn't say whether it was from anticipation or fear. There was something in Marcus's tone, a vulnerability that he'd never heard before, that suggested they were approaching territory neither of them had mapped yet.

"What do you mean?" Andrius asked, though part of him wasn't sure he was ready for the answer. The sheep had gathered under the old oak tree nearby, their woolly forms pressed together for warmth and shelter, and he found himself envying their simple understanding of comfort and safety.

Marcus ran a hand through his wet hair, sending droplets flying, and for a moment he looked younger than his twenty-eight years. The confident graphic designer who created glossy advertisements and sleek websites seemed to have been washed away by the rain, leaving behind someone more uncertain but infinitely more real. "The truth is, when I was talking about getting a tattoo of something meaningful, someone meaningful, I wasn't speaking hypothetically. I know exactly what I want to get, and I know exactly why." He took a step closer, close enough that Andrius could see the water droplets clinging to his eyelashes, could smell the clean scent of rain and something indefinably Marcus underneath. "The question is whether I'm brave enough to actually do it."

Andrius felt the world narrow to just the two of them standing there in the rain, the familiar landscape of his daily life fading into soft focus around the edges. Every instinct he'd developed over seven years of quiet, predictable mornings was telling him that they were balanced on the edge of something that would change everything, that there would be a before this conversation and an after it, with no going back to the comfortable ambiguity they'd been living in. The practical part of his mind, the part that sounded like his father's voice, was urging him to deflect, to make a joke or change the subject, to preserve the friendship they had rather than risk it for something uncertain and potentially catastrophic.

But there was another voice, quieter but more insistent, that had been growing stronger with each passing morning spent in Marcus's company. It was the voice that made him look forward to bedtime not for rest but because sleep brought him closer to dawn, closer to that moment when a familiar figure would appear on the eastern trail. It was the voice that had started composing things to tell Marcus during the long afternoons spent alone with the sheep, collecting small observations and thoughts like gifts he might offer. It was the voice that had been asking increasingly dangerous questions about why his pulse quickened when Marcus smiled at him in that particular way, why he'd started paying attention to the way Marcus's running clothes clung to his lean frame, why the casual endearment "shepherd boy" made something warm and hopeful unfurl in his chest.

"Brave enough for what?" he heard himself asking, though his voice sounded strange and distant to his own ears. The rain was coming down harder now, turning the earth beneath their feet into something soft and yielding, and Andrius had the wild thought that they were being gradually dissolved, that the familiar boundaries of who they were and what they meant to each other were being washed away as surely as the morning mist.

Marcus's smile was different than any Andrius had seen before, tremulous and hopeful and terrified all at once. When he spoke, his words came out in a rush, as if he were afraid that stopping would give him time to reconsider and retreat back into safety. "Brave enough to tell you that these morning conversations have become the best part of my day, that I've started taking longer routes home just to make the feeling last. Brave enough to admit that I've been learning things about sheep and weather patterns and Lithuanian folk songs because I want to understand the world that shaped you. Brave enough to say that when I talk about getting a tattoo of something meaningful, what I'm really thinking about is finding a way to carry a piece of this, of us, of these mornings, with me always."

The silence that followed felt enormous, filled with the sound of rain and the distant bleating of sheep and the thunderous beating of Andrius's own heart. He stared at Marcus's face, searching for signs that this was some kind of elaborate joke or misunderstanding, but finding only sincerity and a hope so fragile it made his chest ache. All the careful walls he'd built around his feelings, the elaborate justifications he'd constructed for why their friendship was simply friendship and nothing more, crumbled like sand castles hit by an unexpected wave.

For seven years, his life had followed predictable rhythms, marked by seasons and weather and the needs of his flock. He'd convinced himself that he was content with solitude, that the peace of his hilltop pasture and the satisfaction of honest work were enough to fill the spaces in his life that sometimes echoed with loneliness. He'd dated occasionally, proper relationships with nice women from town that his family approved of but that never seemed to take root, and he'd told himself that he simply wasn't the settling-down type, that he was too set in his ways, too devoted to his simple life to accommodate another person's needs and dreams.

But standing there in the rain with Marcus looking at him like he held the answer to some crucial question, Andrius realized that all of his rationalizations had been just that. The truth was that he'd never felt for anyone what he felt for this city boy who appeared on his hill each morning like some kind of miracle, never experienced this particular combination of peace and excitement, comfort and longing. Marcus made him want to be braver, more articulate, more worthy of the gift of being truly seen and understood by another person.**Chapter 2**

The rain had stopped by the time Andrius finally found the courage to speak, leaving behind a world that seemed newly washed and gleaming with possibility. Water dripped steadily from the oak tree's branches, creating a gentle percussion against the wet earth, and somewhere in the distance a meadowlark called out its liquid song. The silence between them had stretched long enough to become almost unbearable, filled with Marcus's vulnerable confession hanging in the air like morning mist, waiting for a response that would either nurture it or burn it away entirely.

"I've been thinking about you too," Andrius said finally, the words coming out rougher and more accented than usual, the way his English always became when his emotions were running high. "More than thinking, if I'm being honest. These past three months, I find myself looking forward to dawn in a way I never have before, not because of the sunrise or the quiet or any of the things I used to treasure about mornings, but because of the moment when you appear on that ridge and I know my day is really beginning." He gestured toward the eastern trail where Marcus always emerged, his hand shaking slightly with nervous energy. "I've never been good with words the way you are, never knew how to make feelings sound like poetry, but what you just said about carrying pieces of this with you always, that's exactly what I've been trying to figure out how to tell you for weeks now."

Marcus's face transformed as Andrius spoke, hope blooming across his features like flowers opening to unexpected sunlight. He took another step closer, close enough now that Andrius could count the individual raindrops still clinging to his dark eyelashes, could see the pulse beating rapidly at the base of his throat. The space between them felt charged with electricity, like the air before a thunderstorm, and Andrius found himself holding his breath without quite knowing why. Everything about this moment felt simultaneously inevitable and impossible, as if they'd been walking toward it since that very first morning when Marcus had stopped to ask directions and somehow ended up staying for an hour-long conversation about the migration patterns of local birds.

"I keep having this recurring dream," Marcus said softly, his voice barely audible over the sound of water dripping from the trees around them. "I'm standing in my apartment in the city, looking out the window at all the glass and concrete and hurrying people, and I can't breathe. The air feels thick and artificial, like it's been recycled through too many machines, and I realize I'm suffocating slowly without even knowing it. But then I hear this sound, like wind through grass, and suddenly I'm here, on this hill, and I can breathe again. The dream always ends the same way, with me trying to figure out how to stay, how to build a bridge between the two worlds so I don't have to choose between them."

The vulnerability in Marcus's voice made something twist painfully in Andrius's chest, a mixture of tenderness and fierce protectiveness that caught him off guard with its intensity. He'd always thought of Marcus as belonging entirely to that glittering world of deadlines and client meetings and urban sophistication, had never imagined that the city might feel like a cage rather than a kingdom. The idea that Marcus might be as torn between worlds as Andrius sometimes felt himself to be opened up possibilities that were both thrilling and terrifying in their implications.

"You don't have to choose," Andrius heard himself saying, though he wasn't entirely sure where the certainty in his voice was coming from. "Maybe there's a third option, something neither of us has thought of yet. I know it sounds crazy, but what if the bridge you're dreaming about isn't a metaphor? What if it's something we could actually build?" He gestured toward the farmhouse visible in the distance, its weathered stone walls and red tile roof looking solid and permanent against the gray sky. "I have more land than I know what to do with, and internet service finally made it out here last year. There's no reason someone couldn't work remotely from here, if they wanted to. If they found something worth staying for."

Even as the words left his mouth, Andrius couldn't quite believe he was saying them. Three hours ago, he'd been a bachelor shepherd living a predictably solitary life, and now he was essentially inviting a man he'd known for three months to move in with him. The practical part of his mind was screaming warnings about moving too fast, about the dangers of mixing friendship with romance, about the thousand ways this could end in disaster and heartbreak. But there was another part of him, deeper and more fundamental, that recognized something essential and true in what was happening between them, something that transcended practical concerns and conventional timelines.

Marcus's eyes widened with surprise and something that might have been hope, but before he could respond, the sound of a car engine rumbling up the gravel road interrupted the intimacy of the moment. Andrius turned to see his neighbor Tom's pickup truck approaching, the elderly farmer no doubt coming to discuss the shared fence line they'd been meaning to repair before winter set in. The timing was spectacularly terrible, and Andrius felt a surge of frustration at having their crucial conversation interrupted just as it was reaching what felt like a turning point.

"That's Tom Morrison," he explained to Marcus, who was already stepping back and assuming a more casual posture, though the intensity in his eyes hadn't dimmed. "He owns the adjacent property. I should probably..." He trailed off, torn between politeness and the desperate need to finish what they'd started. This conversation felt too important to leave hanging, too fragile to survive being postponed until tomorrow morning.

"Go," Marcus said, understanding immediately. "Talk to your neighbor. I need to get back to the city anyway, I've got that client meeting in an hour and I'm already going to be cutting it close." But he reached out as he spoke, his fingers brushing against Andrius's hand in a touch that was brief but electric. "But Andrius, we're not done talking about this. About any of this. There's too much at stake now to pretend we can go back to the way things were before."

The touch lingered even after Marcus pulled his hand away, leaving Andrius's skin tingling with awareness and possibility. He watched as Marcus turned and began jogging back toward the city, his yellow rain jacket bright against the muted colors of the wet landscape, and felt something shift permanently in his chest. Whatever happened next, whatever they decided to do about the feelings they'd finally acknowledged, nothing would ever be quite the same again. The comfortable predictability of his solitary life had been irrevocably altered by the admission that he didn't want to be alone anymore, at least not if being with someone meant being with Marcus.

Tom's truck pulled to a stop near the pasture gate, and the older man climbed out with the careful movements of someone whose joints protested against damp weather. He'd been farming the adjacent land for forty years, had known Andrius since he was a boy helping his father with the sheep, and his weathered face creased into a knowing smile as he watched Marcus's retreating figure disappear over the ridge.

"That the young man who's been making you whistle while you work lately?" Tom asked with the directness that came from decades of rural living, where everyone knew everyone else's business and subtlety was considered a waste of time. "Sarah mentioned she saw him running through here most mornings, said you two seemed to have quite the friendship developing." Sarah was Tom's wife, and her network of local information was more reliable than any newspaper or internet forum. Nothing happened in the countryside around Kitchener without Sarah Morrison knowing about it within twenty-four hours.

Andrius felt heat rise in his cheeks, though whether from embarrassment or something else entirely, he couldn't say. The idea that his feelings had been obvious enough for the neighbors to notice was both mortifying and oddly liberating. He'd spent so much energy trying to convince himself that his friendship with Marcus was perfectly ordinary that he hadn't considered how it might look from the outside, how his entire demeanor might have changed over the past three months without his realizing it.

"His name is Marcus," Andrius said carefully, testing how it felt to claim that connection publicly. "He's a graphic designer from the city. We've become friends." The words felt inadequate to describe what had just passed between them on the rain-soaked hill, but he wasn't ready to put anything more definitive into language yet, wasn't sure he had the vocabulary for feelings this new and complicated.

Tom nodded thoughtfully, his keen blue eyes studying Andrius's face with the patience of someone who'd spent a lifetime reading the subtle signs of weather and animal behavior and human nature. "Friendship's a good foundation," he said finally. "Your grandmother always said the best partnerships are built on genuine liking first, everything else second. Smart woman, your babushka. Knew things about the heart that took me years to figure out on my own." He adjusted his baseball cap against the lingering drizzle and looked out over the pasture where the sheep were beginning to emerge from their shelter now that the rain had stopped. "Speaking of partnerships, I came over to talk about that fence repair we discussed, but it can wait if you've got more important things on your mind."

The offer of postponement was kind, but Andrius found himself grateful for the distraction of practical concerns. His emotions felt too raw and overwhelming to examine directly right now, and the familiar rhythm of discussing posts and wire and weather-resistant materials would give him time to process what had just happened. Besides, Tom Morrison had been a steady presence in his life since childhood, and his quiet wisdom had guided Andrius through more than one crisis over the years. If anyone could help him make sense of his current situation, it would be this man who'd managed to balance farming and family for four decades with apparent contentment.

They spent the next hour walking the fence line, discussing repairs and improvements with the thoroughness that rural people brought to all practical matters. The work would need to be done before the first hard frost, which meant they had perhaps three weeks if the weather held. Tom's oldest son Jake would help with the heavy lifting, and they could probably get everything finished in two long days if they planned it right. The familiar cadence of planning and preparation was soothing, grounding Andrius back in the solid realities of his daily life even as part of his mind remained focused on Marcus's confession and his own startling response.As they worked their way along the property line, Tom maintained the comfortable silence that was his trademark, speaking only when necessary to point out a loose post or suggest a better approach to a particular section. But Andrius could sense the older man's attention, the way he seemed to be waiting for something, and finally the weight of unspoken thoughts became too much to bear.

"Tom," Andrius said, stopping beside a section where the wire had been damaged by a fallen branch during the last storm, "can I ask you something? About how you knew Sarah was the one, I mean. How you made the decision to build a life together when everything about it seemed impossible at first." The question came out more direct than he'd intended, but there was something about Tom's steady presence that made honesty feel safer than deflection.

Tom smiled, the expression transforming his weathered features into something surprisingly gentle. He pulled off his work gloves and tucked them into his back pocket, then leaned against the fence post with the air of a man settling in for a longer conversation. "Well now, that's a story I haven't told in a while. You know, when I first met Sarah, she was working at that fancy hotel in Toronto, had ambitions of moving to New York City and becoming some kind of fashion designer. I was just a farm boy from Kitchener who'd never been farther from home than London, Ontario. On paper, we made about as much sense as a fish trying to climb a tree." He chuckled at the memory, his eyes taking on the distant look that came with revisiting the past. "But there was something about the way she looked at the world, like she could see possibilities everywhere, that made me want to be braver than I'd ever been before. And apparently, there was something about my stubborn optimism that made her want to slow down long enough to notice what was right in front of her."

Andrius found himself hanging on every word, searching for parallels to his own situation in Tom's decades-old romance. The idea that two people from completely different worlds could find common ground seemed both inspiring and impossibly romantic, the kind of thing that happened in movies but rarely in real life. Yet here was Tom, living proof that sometimes the most unlikely partnerships were also the most enduring ones.

"The thing is," Tom continued, picking up a small stone and turning it over in his calloused hands, "love isn't really about finding someone who fits perfectly into your existing life. It's about finding someone who makes you want to build something entirely new, something that's bigger and better than what either of you could create alone. Sarah never did make it to New York, but she started her own design business right here in Kitchener, and it's been more successful than anything she could have imagined back then. And I never did become the simple bachelor farmer my father expected me to be. Instead, I became someone who could appreciate art and fashion and city dreams, someone who learned that the world was bigger and more beautiful than I'd ever realized when I was living in it alone."

The parallels were unmistakable, and Andrius felt something loosen in his chest, a knot of anxiety he hadn't even realized he'd been carrying. The fear that caring for Marcus meant abandoning his own identity, his connection to the land and the life his family had built here, suddenly seemed less insurmountable. Maybe love wasn't about choosing between different worlds but about creating space for both to coexist, finding ways to honor the past while embracing the possibility of an unexpected future.

"How did you know it was worth the risk?" Andrius asked, voicing the question that had been haunting him since Marcus's confession that morning. "How did you know that what you were feeling was real enough to base a life on, rather than just infatuation or loneliness or wishful thinking?"

Tom was quiet for a long moment, studying Andrius's face with the same careful attention he'd given to the damaged fence line. When he finally spoke, his voice carried the weight of hard-won wisdom and absolute certainty. "Son, I knew it was real because being with Sarah made me feel like the best possible version of myself, not someone different but someone more complete. When you find yourself wanting to share every small moment with another person, when their happiness becomes as important to you as your own, when you can imagine growing old together and the thought fills you with excitement rather than fear, that's when you know you've found something worth building a life around." He straightened up and pulled his gloves back on, signaling that their philosophical discussion was drawing to a close. "The question isn't whether what you're feeling is real, Andrius. The question is whether you're brave enough to trust it."

The words hit home with uncomfortable accuracy, cutting straight through all the elaborate justifications and fears Andrius had been constructing around his feelings for Marcus. He'd been so focused on all the ways their relationship might fail, all the practical obstacles and social complications, that he'd lost sight of the simple truth Tom had just articulated. What he felt for Marcus wasn't complicated or mysterious or impossible to understand. It was love, pure and straightforward and absolutely terrifying in its implications. The only question now was what he intended to do about it.

They finished their survey of the fence line in companionable silence, marking the spots that would need the most work and estimating materials and time with the precision that came from years of experience. But even as Andrius went through the familiar motions of practical planning, part of his mind was already racing ahead to tomorrow morning, to the moment when Marcus would appear on the eastern trail and they would have to continue the conversation that had been interrupted by Tom's arrival. The thought filled him with equal measures of anticipation and terror, but underneath both emotions was a deeper current of certainty that surprised him with its strength. Whatever happened next, he wasn't going to let fear make his decisions for him anymore.

By the time Tom drove away, promising to return the following weekend with Jake and a truck full of supplies, the afternoon shadows were lengthening and the sheep had begun their slow migration toward the barn for evening feeding. Andrius went through his daily routines automatically, his hands performing tasks they'd done thousands of times while his mind remained focused on the morning's revelations and Tom's sage advice. The familiar rhythm of caring for his flock was soothing, but it couldn't entirely quiet the nervous energy that seemed to be humming through his entire body like electricity.

That evening, he found himself standing in front of the bathroom mirror for longer than usual, studying his reflection with the kind of critical attention he normally reserved for evaluating the health of his animals. At thirty-one, he still looked young enough, though seven years of outdoor work had left their mark in the fine lines around his eyes and the permanent tan that no amount of winter could fade completely. His dark hair, inherited from his Lithuanian grandfather along with his unusual surname, was still thick and unruly despite his attempts to tame it with increasingly expensive products from the pharmacy in town. He wondered what Marcus saw when he looked at him, whether the attraction he'd sensed that morning was real or just wishful thinking on his part.

The thought led him to his bedroom closet, where he found himself examining his limited wardrobe with newfound dissatisfaction. Most of his clothes were practical rather than fashionable, chosen for durability and weather resistance rather than style or appeal. He owned exactly two button-down shirts that weren't flannel, three pairs of jeans that weren't work-stained, and one suit that he'd bought for his cousin's wedding two years ago and hadn't worn since. The contrast between his rural practicality and Marcus's urban sophistication had never seemed more pronounced, and for a moment he felt a familiar wave of insecurity about the vast differences in their backgrounds and lifestyles.

But then he remembered Tom's words about love making space for different worlds to coexist, and the anxiety began to transform into something more like determination. Maybe he couldn't compete with the city in terms of restaurants and culture and career opportunities, but he had other things to offer, things that Marcus seemed to value and appreciate. The peace of wide-open spaces, the satisfaction of work that connected directly to the natural world, the kind of quiet contentment that came from living in harmony with the rhythms of weather and season and growing things. If Marcus was serious about wanting to build a bridge between their two worlds, then Andrius needed to trust that his own world had value worth bridging toward.

His phone buzzed with another text message, and this time he didn't hesitate to check it immediately. Marcus had sent a photo of the coffee shop mural he'd mentioned that morning, a vibrant explosion of color and movement that seemed to capture the energy of urban life in abstract form. Below the image was a message: "Spent my lunch break sketching ideas for that tattoo I mentioned. Keep thinking about wide open spaces and morning light and the way you look when you're completely content. Hope that's not too weird to say. See you tomorrow, shepherd boy."

Andrius stared at the message for a long time, reading it over and over until he had every word memorized. The casual intimacy of it, the way Marcus seemed to see beauty in moments that Andrius had never considered particularly notable, filled him with a warmth that had nothing to do with the temperature of his small farmhouse kitchen. He typed and deleted several responses before finally settling on: "Not weird at all. I've been thinking about you too. More than thinking, actually. We have a lot to talk about tomorrow."

It wasn't poetry, but it was honest, and honesty seemed more important than eloquence at this particular moment in his life. He sent the message before he could second-guess himself, then spent the rest of the evening in a state of nervous anticipation that made it impossible to concentrate on anything more demanding than mindless television. Sleep, when it finally came, was filled with dreams of yellow rain jackets and warm brown eyes and conversations that seemed to stretch endlessly under wide morning skies.

The next day dawned clear and crisp, with the kind of brilliant autumn sunshine that made every color seem more vivid and intense. Andrius was up before his alarm, moving through his morning routine with an efficiency born of nervous energy and anticipation. The sheep seemed to sense his mood, gathering around him with unusual attention as he checked their water and distributed fresh hay. Marcus had grown to appreciate these informal visits from neighbors who felt comfortable dropping by without advance notice, treating their property as part of an extended community space where important information and mutual support were shared through face-to-face conversation rather than digital communication.

"Evening, you two," Tom called out as he approached the porch, his voice carrying the satisfaction that came from completing a productive day's work combined with curiosity about how their inaugural workshop had proceeded. "Sarah sent me over to get a full report on how your teaching debut went today, since she spent most of the afternoon watching from our kitchen window and was impressed by how professional everything looked from a distance. She also wanted me to let you know that she's been fielding phone calls all evening from people who heard about your workshop and want to know when you're planning the next one, which suggests that word is spreading faster than you might have expected."

The news that their workshop had generated immediate community interest and positive word-of-mouth publicity pleased Marcus even more than the financial success and participant satisfaction they had already confirmed, because it suggested that their educational venture was being perceived as a valuable community asset rather than simply a private business enterprise. The distinction was important for their long-term sustainability and their goals for contributing meaningfully to rural economic development and community resilience. If their programming could attract visitors who contributed to the broader regional economy while also providing educational experiences that benefited both urban and rural residents, they would be creating exactly the kind of bridge between different communities that had been missing from previous agritourism and educational initiatives.

Tom settled into one of the porch chairs with the comfortable familiarity that characterized his interactions with their household, accepting Andrius's offer of a cold drink and preparing to engage in the kind of extended conversation that rural social customs encouraged during pleasant evening weather. His presence transformed their private reflection into a community discussion that included perspectives shaped by decades of experience with agricultural education, rural economic development, and the social dynamics that influenced the success or failure of collaborative ventures in small communities. The fact that he had taken the initiative to visit and discuss their activities demonstrated the kind of supportive interest that could make the difference between individual success and broader community impact.

"The workshop went better than we dared to hope," Marcus reported, his enthusiasm evident as he described the diversity of participants, the quality of their questions and engagement, and the positive feedback they had received about both the educational content and the authentic farm atmosphere. "We had people from the city who had never touched a sheep, teenagers from the regional high school who knew more about agriculture than some of the adults, and families who were looking for weekend activities that could combine entertainment with genuine learning opportunities. The fact that everyone seemed to find something valuable despite their very different backgrounds and interests makes me think we've identified an approach that could work for much larger and more diverse audiences."

Tom nodded with the kind of approval that came from recognizing successful community development when he saw it, his expression combining personal satisfaction with their achievements and strategic assessment of the broader implications for regional economic sustainability and rural community vitality. His decades of involvement in various collaborative agricultural and educational initiatives had given him perspective on the factors that determined whether individual successes could be translated into lasting benefits for entire communities, and his questions about their future plans reflected understanding of both the opportunities and challenges that lay ahead as they attempted to scale their initial success.

The morning mist clung to the rolling hills outside Kitchener like a gossamer shroud, and Andrius Kavaliauskas pulled his worn woolen coat tighter against the October chill. His breath formed small clouds in the crisp air as he counted his flock, the familiar ritual bringing him the same quiet satisfaction it had for the past seven years. Twenty-three sheep, all accounted for, their woolly forms dotting the green pasture like scattered cotton balls against an emerald canvas.

From the ridge above, he could see the city sprawling in the distance, its glass towers catching the first golden rays of sunrise. Sometimes he wondered what it would be like to live among all those people, rushing about their daily business in suits and ties, but the thought never lingered long. This was his world, simple and peaceful, where the biggest concern was whether old Bertha would wander too close to the creek again or if the weather would hold for another week of good grazing.

A whistle echoed across the valley, and Andrius felt his heart skip in that familiar way it had been doing lately. Marcus was approaching from the eastern trail, his tall frame silhouetted against the brightening sky. They had been meeting like this almost every morning for three months now, ever since Marcus had started taking his daily runs through the countryside to escape what he called "the suffocating embrace of suburban life."

Marcus Chen worked as a graphic designer downtown, something that seemed impossibly glamorous and mysterious to Andrius, though he would never admit it. While Andrius spent his days with sheep and sky and the whisper of wind through grass, Marcus created advertisements and logos and websites for companies whose names Andrius couldn't even pronounce properly. Yet somehow, despite their vastly different worlds, they had fallen into an easy friendship that felt as natural as breathing.

"Morning, shepherd boy," Marcus called out as he jogged closer, his running shoes squelching slightly in the dew-damp earth. His dark hair was tousled from the wind, and there was a flush in his cheeks that made Andrius's stomach flutter in ways he was still trying to understand.

"Morning, city boy," Andrius replied with a grin, using their usual greeting. "You're later than normal. Traffic jam on the trail?"

Marcus laughed, bending over to catch his breath. He was wearing those tight running clothes that made Andrius forget what he was saying sometimes. "Actually, I got distracted by something interesting on my way here. There's this new coffee shop that just opened on King Street, and they've got this amazing mural on the side wall. Made me think about art and permanence and all that philosophical stuff that keeps me up at night."

This was one of the things Andrius loved most about Marcus, the way his mind worked, jumping from topic to topic like a butterfly sampling flowers. Andrius's own thoughts moved more like his sheep, steady and purposeful and occasionally stubborn. Together, they seemed to balance each other out in a way that felt almost magical.

"Speaking of permanent things," Marcus continued, straightening up and walking closer, "I've been thinking about getting a tattoo. Something meaningful, you know? Not just some random design, but something that represents who I am, where I come from, what matters to me."

Andrius felt something twist in his chest, though he couldn't quite identify what it was. "What kind of tattoo?"

"I'm not sure yet. Maybe something that incorporates my heritage, or represents my work, or..." Marcus paused, looking directly at Andrius with those warm brown eyes that seemed to see straight through to his soul. "Or maybe something that represents the people who've become important to me."

The air between them seemed to shimmer with unspoken possibilities, and Andrius felt his mouth go dry. He wanted to say something meaningful, something that would let Marcus know how much their friendship meant to him, how the best part of his day was always this moment when Marcus appeared on the horizon. But the words felt too big and dangerous, so instead he just nodded and looked out over his flock.

"That sounds nice," he managed finally, his voice coming out rougher than intended.

Marcus was quiet for a moment, and when Andrius glanced back at him, there was something almost disappointed in his expression. But it passed so quickly that Andrius wondered if he had imagined it.

"Anyway," Marcus said, his tone becoming more casual, "I should probably head back soon. I've got a client meeting at nine, and I still need to shower and pretend I'm a responsible adult who doesn't spend his mornings running around talking to sheep herders."

"Shepherds," Andrius corrected automatically.

"Right, shepherds. Much more dignified." Marcus's smile was teasing, but there was genuine warmth in it that made Andrius's chest feel tight. "Same time tomorrow?"

"Same time tomorrow," Andrius agreed, watching as Marcus turned and began jogging back toward the city. He stood there until the other man disappeared over the ridge, then spent the rest of the morning trying to convince himself that the strange ache in his chest was just indigestion from the leftover pierogi he'd eaten for breakfast.

That evening, Andrius sat at his small kitchen table, a cup of tea growing cold in his hands as he stared out the window toward the lights of Kitchener twinkling in the distance. The farmhouse had belonged to his grandfather, then his father, and now him, each generation adding their own touches while maintaining the essential character of the place. The wooden floors creaked with familiar sounds, and the walls held the accumulated warmth of decades of family meals and quiet conversations. It was a good life, he reminded himself, exactly the kind of life his grandparents had dreamed of when they first immigrated from Lithuania with nothing but hope and determination.

But tonight, something felt different. Marcus's words about tattoos and meaningful things kept echoing in his mind, along with that look he'd given him, as if he were waiting for Andrius to say something important. The problem was, Andrius had never been good with words, especially when his feelings were involved. Growing up in a family where emotions were expressed through actions rather than declarations had left him woefully unprepared for moments that seemed to require poetry.

His phone buzzed on the table, and he nearly knocked over his tea cup in his haste to check it. A text from Marcus: "Thanks for listening to me ramble about tattoos this morning. Sometimes I think you're the only person who actually hears what I'm trying to say." There was a pause, then another message: "Do you ever feel like you're living two different lives? Like there's the person you are in public and then there's who you really are when no one's watching?"

Andrius stared at the screen for a long time, his thumbs hovering over the keyboard. He wanted to tell Marcus that yes, he understood exactly what that felt like, that sometimes he felt like he was performing the role of the simple shepherd when inside he was someone much more complicated. He wanted to say that the only time he felt completely himself was during those morning conversations on the hill, when the rest of the world seemed to fade away and it was just the two of them and the endless sky. Instead, he typed back: "I think everyone feels that way sometimes."

It wasn't enough, he knew as soon as he hit send. It was safe and noncommittal and probably not what Marcus needed to hear. But before he could figure out how to say what he really meant, Marcus had replied: "You're probably right. I should let you get some sleep. Sweet dreams, shepherd boy."

Andrius set the phone aside and rubbed his temples, frustrated with himself and his inability to bridge the gap between what he felt and what he could express. Outside, he could hear the sheep settling in for the night, their soft bleating carrying on the autumn breeze. Tomorrow would bring another morning, another chance to get it right, but he couldn't shake the feeling that opportunities were slipping through his fingers like water.

The next morning dawned gray and overcast, with the kind of persistent drizzle that seemed designed to dampen spirits as well as clothing. Andrius pulled on his rain jacket and made his usual rounds, checking on the flock and making sure they had adequate shelter from the weather. The sheep seemed unbothered by the rain, but Andrius found himself glancing repeatedly toward the eastern trail, wondering if Marcus would still come for his run in conditions like these.

When the familiar whistle finally echoed across the valley, Andrius felt a relief so profound it surprised him. Marcus appeared through the mist wearing a bright yellow rain jacket that made him look like a beam of sunshine against the gray landscape. His hair was plastered to his head, and he was grinning with the kind of reckless joy that came from embracing rather than fighting the elements.

"Crazy weather for a run," Andrius called out as Marcus approached, having to raise his voice slightly over the sound of rain pattering against his jacket hood.

"Are you kidding? This is perfect weather for thinking," Marcus replied, shaking droplets from his hands. "There's something about rain that makes everything feel more honest, don't you think? Like it washes away all the pretense and leaves just the essential stuff behind." He paused, studying Andrius's face with that intense way he had that made Andrius feel simultaneously seen and exposed. "I've been thinking about our conversation yesterday, about tattoos and meaningful things. And I realized I wasn't being completely honest."

The rain seemed to intensify around them as Marcus spoke, creating a curtain of privacy that made the moment feel suspended from the ordinary world. Andrius felt his heart begin to beat faster, though he couldn't say whether it was from anticipation or fear. There was something in Marcus's tone, a vulnerability that he'd never heard before, that suggested they were approaching territory neither of them had mapped yet.

"What do you mean?" Andrius asked, though part of him wasn't sure he was ready for the answer. The sheep had gathered under the old oak tree nearby, their woolly forms pressed together for warmth and shelter, and he found himself envying their simple understanding of comfort and safety.

Marcus ran a hand through his wet hair, sending droplets flying, and for a moment he looked younger than his twenty-eight years. The confident graphic designer who created glossy advertisements and sleek websites seemed to have been washed away by the rain, leaving behind someone more uncertain but infinitely more real. "The truth is, when I was talking about getting a tattoo of something meaningful, someone meaningful, I wasn't speaking hypothetically. I know exactly what I want to get, and I know exactly why." He took a step closer, close enough that Andrius could see the water droplets clinging to his eyelashes, could smell the clean scent of rain and something indefinably Marcus underneath. "The question is whether I'm brave enough to actually do it."

Andrius felt the world narrow to just the two of them standing there in the rain, the familiar landscape of his daily life fading into soft focus around the edges. Every instinct he'd developed over seven years of quiet, predictable mornings was telling him that they were balanced on the edge of something that would change everything, that there would be a before this conversation and an after it, with no going back to the comfortable ambiguity they'd been living in. The practical part of his mind, the part that sounded like his father's voice, was urging him to deflect, to make a joke or change the subject, to preserve the friendship they had rather than risk it for something uncertain and potentially catastrophic.

But there was another voice, quieter but more insistent, that had been growing stronger with each passing morning spent in Marcus's company. It was the voice that made him look forward to bedtime not for rest but because sleep brought him closer to dawn, closer to that moment when a familiar figure would appear on the eastern trail. It was the voice that had started composing things to tell Marcus during the long afternoons spent alone with the sheep, collecting small observations and thoughts like gifts he might offer. It was the voice that had been asking increasingly dangerous questions about why his pulse quickened when Marcus smiled at him in that particular way, why he'd started paying attention to the way Marcus's running clothes clung to his lean frame, why the casual endearment "shepherd boy" made something warm and hopeful unfurl in his chest.

"Brave enough for what?" he heard himself asking, though his voice sounded strange and distant to his own ears. The rain was coming down harder now, turning the earth beneath their feet into something soft and yielding, and Andrius had the wild thought that they were being gradually dissolved, that the familiar boundaries of who they were and what they meant to each other were being washed away as surely as the morning mist.

Marcus's smile was different than any Andrius had seen before, tremulous and hopeful and terrified all at once. When he spoke, his words came out in a rush, as if he were afraid that stopping would give him time to reconsider and retreat back into safety. "Brave enough to tell you that these morning conversations have become the best part of my day, that I've started taking longer routes home just to make the feeling last. Brave enough to admit that I've been learning things about sheep and weather patterns and Lithuanian folk songs because I want to understand the world that shaped you. Brave enough to say that when I talk about getting a tattoo of something meaningful, what I'm really thinking about is finding a way to carry a piece of this, of us, of these mornings, with me always."

The silence that followed felt enormous, filled with the sound of rain and the distant bleating of sheep and the thunderous beating of Andrius's own heart. He stared at Marcus's face, searching for signs that this was some kind of elaborate joke or misunderstanding, but finding only sincerity and a hope so fragile it made his chest ache. All the careful walls he'd built around his feelings, the elaborate justifications he'd constructed for why their friendship was simply friendship and nothing more, crumbled like sand castles hit by an unexpected wave.

For seven years, his life had followed predictable rhythms, marked by seasons and weather and the needs of his flock. He'd convinced himself that he was content with solitude, that the peace of his hilltop pasture and the satisfaction of honest work were enough to fill the spaces in his life that sometimes echoed with loneliness. He'd dated occasionally, proper relationships with nice women from town that his family approved of but that never seemed to take root, and he'd told himself that he simply wasn't the settling-down type, that he was too set in his ways, too devoted to his simple life to accommodate another person's needs and dreams.

But standing there in the rain with Marcus looking at him like he held the answer to some crucial question, Andrius realized that all of his rationalizations had been just that. The truth was that he'd never felt for anyone what he felt for this city boy who appeared on his hill each morning like some kind of miracle, never experienced this particular combination of peace and excitement, comfort and longing. Marcus made him want to be braver, more articulate, more worthy of the gift of being truly seen and understood by another person.

**Chapter 2**

The rain had stopped by the time Andrius finally found the courage to speak, leaving behind a world that seemed newly washed and gleaming with possibility. Water dripped steadily from the oak tree's branches, creating a gentle percussion against the wet earth, and somewhere in the distance a meadowlark called out its liquid song. The silence between them had stretched long enough to become almost unbearable, filled with Marcus's vulnerable confession hanging in the air like morning mist, waiting for a response that would either nurture it or burn it away entirely.

"I've been thinking about you too," Andrius said finally, the words coming out rougher and more accented than usual, the way his English always became when his emotions were running high. "More than thinking, if I'm being honest. These past three months, I find myself looking forward to dawn in a way I never have before, not because of the sunrise or the quiet or any of the things I used to treasure about mornings, but because of the moment when you appear on that ridge and I know my day is really beginning." He gestured toward the eastern trail where Marcus always emerged, his hand shaking slightly with nervous energy. "I've never been good with words the way you are, never knew how to make feelings sound like poetry, but what you just said about carrying pieces of this with you always, that's exactly what I've been trying to figure out how to tell you for weeks now."

Marcus's face transformed as Andrius spoke, hope blooming across his features like flowers opening to unexpected sunlight. He took another step closer, close enough now that Andrius could count the individual raindrops still clinging to his dark eyelashes, could see the pulse beating rapidly at the base of his throat. The space between them felt charged with electricity, like the air before a thunderstorm, and Andrius found himself holding his breath without quite knowing why. Everything about this moment felt simultaneously inevitable and impossible, as if they'd been walking toward it since that very first morning when Marcus had stopped to ask directions and somehow ended up staying for an hour-long conversation about the migration patterns of local birds.

"I keep having this recurring dream," Marcus said softly, his voice barely audible over the sound of water dripping from the trees around them. "I'm standing in my apartment in the city, looking out the window at all the glass and concrete and hurrying people, and I can't breathe. The air feels thick and artificial, like it's been recycled through too many machines, and I realize I'm suffocating slowly without even knowing it. But then I hear this sound, like wind through grass, and suddenly I'm here, on this hill, and I can breathe again. The dream always ends the same way, with me trying to figure out how to stay, how to build a bridge between the two worlds so I don't have to choose between them."

The vulnerability in Marcus's voice made something twist painfully in Andrius's chest, a mixture of tenderness and fierce protectiveness that caught him off guard with its intensity. He'd always thought of Marcus as belonging entirely to that glittering world of deadlines and client meetings and urban sophistication, had never imagined that the city might feel like a cage rather than a kingdom. The idea that Marcus might be as torn between worlds as Andrius sometimes felt himself to be opened up possibilities that were both thrilling and terrifying in their implications.

"You don't have to choose," Andrius heard himself saying, though he wasn't entirely sure where the certainty in his voice was coming from. "Maybe there's a third option, something neither of us has thought of yet. I know it sounds crazy, but what if the bridge you're dreaming about isn't a metaphor? What if it's something we could actually build?" He gestured toward the farmhouse visible in the distance, its weathered stone walls and red tile roof looking solid and permanent against the gray sky. "I have more land than I know what to do with, and internet service finally made it out here last year. There's no reason someone couldn't work remotely from here, if they wanted to. If they found something worth staying for."

Even as the words left his mouth, Andrius couldn't quite believe he was saying them. Three hours ago, he'd been a bachelor shepherd living a predictably solitary life, and now he was essentially inviting a man he'd known for three months to move in with him. The practical part of his mind was screaming warnings about moving too fast, about the dangers of mixing friendship with romance, about the thousand ways this could end in disaster and heartbreak. But there was another part of him, deeper and more fundamental, that recognized something essential and true in what was happening between them, something that transcended practical concerns and conventional timelines.

Marcus's eyes widened with surprise and something that might have been hope, but before he could respond, the sound of a car engine rumbling up the gravel road interrupted the intimacy of the moment. Andrius turned to see his neighbor Tom's pickup truck approaching, the elderly farmer no doubt coming to discuss the shared fence line they'd been meaning to repair before winter set in. The timing was spectacularly terrible, and Andrius felt a surge of frustration at having their crucial conversation interrupted just as it was reaching what felt like a turning point.

"That's Tom Morrison," he explained to Marcus, who was already stepping back and assuming a more casual posture, though the intensity in his eyes hadn't dimmed. "He owns the adjacent property. I should probably..." He trailed off, torn between politeness and the desperate need to finish what they'd started. This conversation felt too important to leave hanging, too fragile to survive being postponed until tomorrow morning.

"Go," Marcus said, understanding immediately. "Talk to your neighbor. I need to get back to the city anyway, I've got that client meeting in an hour and I'm already going to be cutting it close." But he reached out as he spoke, his fingers brushing against Andrius's hand in a touch that was brief but electric. "But Andrius, we're not done talking about this. About any of this. There's too much at stake now to pretend we can go back to the way things were before."

The touch lingered even after Marcus pulled his hand away, leaving Andrius's skin tingling with awareness and possibility. He watched as Marcus turned and began jogging back toward the city, his yellow rain jacket bright against the muted colors of the wet landscape, and felt something shift permanently in his chest. Whatever happened next, whatever they decided to do about the feelings they'd finally acknowledged, nothing would ever be quite the same again. The comfortable predictability of his solitary life had been irrevocably altered by the admission that he didn't want to be alone anymore, at least not if being with someone meant being with Marcus.

Tom's truck pulled to a stop near the pasture gate, and the older man climbed out with the careful movements of someone whose joints protested against damp weather. He'd been farming the adjacent land for forty years, had known Andrius since he was a boy helping his father with the sheep, and his weathered face creased into a knowing smile as he watched Marcus's retreating figure disappear over the ridge.

"That the young man who's been making you whistle while you work lately?" Tom asked with the directness that came from decades of rural living, where everyone knew everyone else's business and subtlety was considered a waste of time. "Sarah mentioned she saw him running through here most mornings, said you two seemed to have quite the friendship developing." Sarah was Tom's wife, and her network of local information was more reliable than any newspaper or internet forum. Nothing happened in the countryside around Kitchener without Sarah Morrison knowing about it within twenty-four hours.

Andrius felt heat rise in his cheeks, though whether from embarrassment or something else entirely, he couldn't say. The idea that his feelings had been obvious enough for the neighbors to notice was both mortifying and oddly liberating. He'd spent so much energy trying to convince himself that his friendship with Marcus was perfectly ordinary that he hadn't considered how it might look from the outside, how his entire demeanor might have changed over the past three months without his realizing it.

"His name is Marcus," Andrius said carefully, testing how it felt to claim that connection publicly. "He's a graphic designer from the city. We've become friends." The words felt inadequate to describe what had just passed between them on the rain-soaked hill, but he wasn't ready to put anything more definitive into language yet, wasn't sure he had the vocabulary for feelings this new and complicated.

Tom nodded thoughtfully, his keen blue eyes studying Andrius's face with the patience of someone who'd spent a lifetime reading the subtle signs of weather and animal behavior and human nature. "Friendship's a good foundation," he said finally. "Your grandmother always said the best partnerships are built on genuine liking first, everything else second. Smart woman, your babushka. Knew things about the heart that took me years to figure out on my own." He adjusted his baseball cap against the lingering drizzle and looked out over the pasture where the sheep were beginning to emerge from their shelter now that the rain had stopped. "Speaking of partnerships, I came over to talk about that fence repair we discussed, but it can wait if you've got more important things on your mind."

The offer of postponement was kind, but Andrius found himself grateful for the distraction of practical concerns. His emotions felt too raw and overwhelming to examine directly right now, and the familiar rhythm of discussing posts and wire and weather-resistant materials would give him time to process what had just happened. Besides, Tom Morrison had been a steady presence in his life since childhood, and his quiet wisdom had guided Andrius through more than one crisis over the years. If anyone could help him make sense of his current situation, it would be this man who'd managed to balance farming and family for four decades with apparent contentment.

They spent the next hour walking the fence line, discussing repairs and improvements with the thoroughness that rural people brought to all practical matters. The work would need to be done before the first hard frost, which meant they had perhaps three weeks if the weather held. Tom's oldest son Jake would help with the heavy lifting, and they could probably get everything finished in two long days if they planned it right. The familiar cadence of planning and preparation was soothing, grounding Andrius back in the solid realities of his daily life even as part of his mind remained focused on Marcus's confession and his own startling response.

As they worked their way along the property line, Tom maintained the comfortable silence that was his trademark, speaking only when necessary to point out a loose post or suggest a better approach to a particular section. But Andrius could sense the older man's attention, the way he seemed to be waiting for something, and finally the weight of unspoken thoughts became too much to bear.

"Tom," Andrius said, stopping beside a section where the wire had been damaged by a fallen branch during the last storm, "can I ask you something? About how you knew Sarah was the one, I mean. How you made the decision to build a life together when everything about it seemed impossible at first." The question came out more direct than he'd intended, but there was something about Tom's steady presence that made honesty feel safer than deflection.

Tom smiled, the expression transforming his weathered features into something surprisingly gentle. He pulled off his work gloves and tucked them into his back pocket, then leaned against the fence post with the air of a man settling in for a longer conversation. "Well now, that's a story I haven't told in a while. You know, when I first met Sarah, she was working at that fancy hotel in Toronto, had ambitions of moving to New York City and becoming some kind of fashion designer. I was just a farm boy from Kitchener who'd never been farther from home than London, Ontario. On paper, we made about as much sense as a fish trying to climb a tree." He chuckled at the memory, his eyes taking on the distant look that came with revisiting the past. "But there was something about the way she looked at the world, like she could see possibilities everywhere, that made me want to be braver than I'd ever been before. And apparently, there was something about my stubborn optimism that made her want to slow down long enough to notice what was right in front of her."

Andrius found himself hanging on every word, searching for parallels to his own situation in Tom's decades-old romance. The idea that two people from completely different worlds could find common ground seemed both inspiring and impossibly romantic, the kind of thing that happened in movies but rarely in real life. Yet here was Tom, living proof that sometimes the most unlikely partnerships were also the most enduring ones.

"The thing is," Tom continued, picking up a small stone and turning it over in his calloused hands, "love isn't really about finding someone who fits perfectly into your existing life. It's about finding someone who makes you want to build something entirely new, something that's bigger and better than what either of you could create alone. Sarah never did make it to New York, but she started her own design business right here in Kitchener, and it's been more successful than anything she could have imagined back then. And I never did become the simple bachelor farmer my father expected me to be. Instead, I became someone who could appreciate art and fashion and city dreams, someone who learned that the world was bigger and more beautiful than I'd ever realized when I was living in it alone."

The parallels were unmistakable, and Andrius felt something loosen in his chest, a knot of anxiety he hadn't even realized he'd been carrying. The fear that caring for Marcus meant abandoning his own identity, his connection to the land and the life his family had built here, suddenly seemed less insurmountable. Maybe love wasn't about choosing between different worlds but about creating space for both to coexist, finding ways to honor the past while embracing the possibility of an unexpected future.

"How did you know it was worth the risk?" Andrius asked, voicing the question that had been haunting him since Marcus's confession that morning. "How did you know that what you were feeling was real enough to base a life on, rather than just infatuation or loneliness or wishful thinking?"

Tom was quiet for a long moment, studying Andrius's face with the same careful attention he'd given to the damaged fence line. When he finally spoke, his voice carried the weight of hard-won wisdom and absolute certainty. "Son, I knew it was real because being with Sarah made me feel like the best possible version of myself, not someone different but someone more complete. When you find yourself wanting to share every small moment with another person, when their happiness becomes as important to you as your own, when you can imagine growing old together and the thought fills you with excitement rather than fear, that's when you know you've found something worth building a life around." He straightened up and pulled his gloves back on, signaling that their philosophical discussion was drawing to a close. "The question isn't whether what you're feeling is real, Andrius. The question is whether you're brave enough to trust it."

The words hit home with uncomfortable accuracy, cutting straight through all the elaborate justifications and fears Andrius had been constructing around his feelings for Marcus. He'd been so focused on all the ways their relationship might fail, all the practical obstacles and social complications, that he'd lost sight of the simple truth Tom had just articulated. What he felt for Marcus wasn't complicated or mysterious or impossible to understand. It was love, pure and straightforward and absolutely terrifying in its implications. The only question now was what he intended to do about it.

They finished their survey of the fence line in companionable silence, marking the spots that would need the most work and estimating materials and time with the precision that came from years of experience. But even as Andrius went through the familiar motions of practical planning, part of his mind was already racing ahead to tomorrow morning, to the moment when Marcus would appear on the eastern trail and they would have to continue the conversation that had been interrupted by Tom's arrival. The thought filled him with equal measures of anticipation and terror, but underneath both emotions was a deeper current of certainty that surprised him with its strength. Whatever happened next, he wasn't going to let fear make his decisions for him anymore.

By the time Tom drove away, promising to return the following weekend with Jake and a truck full of supplies, the afternoon shadows were lengthening and the sheep had begun their slow migration toward the barn for evening feeding. Andrius went through his daily routines automatically, his hands performing tasks they'd done thousands of times while his mind remained focused on the morning's revelations and Tom's sage advice. The familiar rhythm of caring for his flock was soothing, but it couldn't entirely quiet the nervous energy that seemed to be humming through his entire body like electricity.

That evening, he found himself standing in front of the bathroom mirror for longer than usual, studying his reflection with the kind of critical attention he normally reserved for evaluating the health of his animals. At thirty-one, he still looked young enough, though seven years of outdoor work had left their mark in the fine lines around his eyes and the permanent tan that no amount of winter could fade completely. His dark hair, inherited from his Lithuanian grandfather along with his unusual surname, was still thick and unruly despite his attempts to tame it with increasingly expensive products from the pharmacy in town. He wondered what Marcus saw when he looked at him, whether the attraction he'd sensed that morning was real or just wishful thinking on his part.
